titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: May.

9. Tuesday— Washington— Morning occupied in preparing for my departure— To the Cars 1. quarter after 5. P.M.— Robert C. Buchanan, and Joseph H. Adams with me—Mrs Gales—W. W. Seaton and his daughters there—N. P. Willis, with his wife and William the page, fellow passengers to Baltimore. Also Miss Seaton.— Lodge at Barnum’s

10. V. Steamer Carroll. Captain Chaytor to Frenchtown. Willis’s fellow passengers, Mrs Williams, her Son and daughter—going to Cambridge. this and another Son Seniors there— Passenger told me of meeting of Merchants at Baltimore last Evening; advised all the Banks to suspend Specie payments— Railway Cars to Newcastle

Steamboat Ohio. Captn. Jenkins to Philadelphia— Arrived at 8. Charles Biddle, with Barouche took me to his father’s— Second dinner. Mr Colt— Banks at New-York suspended Specie payments this day— Condy Raguet—Commodore James Biddle—Charles—Jane—Meta— B. Richards and 2. others left 2. Resolutions of a Meeting of Merchants recommending to all the Banks to suspend specie payments— Mr Biddle all the Evening out.

11. V. Dodd’s Callimachus and Orpheus— Mr Biddle, morning call. Then went to the Bank, and did not return till dinnertime— All the banks suspended— John Connell— Call at B. Rundle’s— Schuylkill permanent Bridge Stock dividends 2 years 120. dollars check, on Bank of Pennsylvania— Took Bills— Visited Benjamin Lundy—went with him to Samuel Webb’s— Afterwards with Connell to see the picture of the departure of the Israĕlites from Egypt— Grandiose Style. Coll. Watmough dined with Mr Biddle— 2 deputies from Baltimore Banks— Evening at Samuel Webb’s, with a convocation of Friends. late home— Symptoms of rioting at the Banks—passed off quietly.

12. V— With Mr Biddle. to Bradford’s— Delphin Classics—Cicero. At the Bank— Gathering of Merchants— Letter to my wife— Took it to the Post-Office— Company at dinner— W. B. Lewis— David Paul Brown Drayton’s odd note— Commodore Biddle—Dr Chapman—Jaudon— Call yesterday at Mrs Clapp’s. Arch Street Theatre— Wags of Windsor Power Looney M’Twolter— Burnet Caleb Quotem

13. V. Saturday— Mr Biddle with me to Steamboat New-Philadelphia— No acquaintance— Bordentown at 9. Railway— Amboy at 11— Steamboat— New-York at 1. Garnetson former Member of Congress from New-Jersey. Several members of the Legislature— Walked over to the foot of Pike-street East river to Steamer Massachusetts. Then walked to Arthur and Lewis Tappan’s Shop, Pearl street. Met Mr Colt— Returned to the Steamboat. Started at 5. P.M— N. P. Willis F. O. J. Smith— Winchester— Calm— Fog at 9 or 10. P.M.

14. VI. Sunday— Fogs coming and going all the morning— Steam slackened—Race— Gull Island— Point Judith—invisible Newport light— Newport 1/2 past 2. Landed Newport passengers— Anchored in Providence river at 3. Cleared off at 1/2 past 3. Providence 1/2 past 5. Railway Cars— Boston 8 P.M— Went to Charles’s house—Gorham Brooks Mr P. C Brooks—

15. VI. Monday— Charles’s Children— After Breakfast he took me out to Quincy— Rain— Went to his house—raised ten days ago— He returned to Boston before dinner— Cold, stormy day— Confined almost to the House— Seminary—Garden-Nursery—Trees mostly destroyed— Reading—Cicero’s Epistles—Horace Epode 2. Wrote to my wife— John Kirke—his wife, and daughter Elizabeth. John Toohey.
16. V:30. Tuesday.

Cold Northeast storm continued all day. Rain with intermission— E. Price Greenleaf brought home books— Visited with me Garden and Nursery— Great Destruction of trees— Black Jack Oak and Honey Locust dead— Nothing but apple seeds out of the ground— Confined almost the whole day to the House— Cicero and Horace— Could not find T... contra Caesarem Audes— 2d. Epode— Wrote almost nothing. S. H. Weed
17. V. Wednesday.

Letter from my wife. 12. May. Catarrhal cough Price Greenleaf brought home the rest of the books. Visits morning from Mr P. Whitney—and J. Q. Adams Evening from G. W. Beale— Charles here this afternoon— Returned to Boston— Cleared off fair and warm. Assorted Letters. Finished the version of 2d Epode. Walk to Mrs A. Adams’s—Mrs Foster and daughter.
18. IV:30. Thursday

Fair morning— Rainy Evening— S. Copeland— Subscription to road from railway to Captains Bridge. promised 20 dollars— Wrote to my wife— Morning from 9 to 12. in garden and Nursery. Trimming trees. Discouraging prospects. President Quincy and his Son here after dinner— Degrand afternoon and Evening— N. Biddle’s 3d. printed Letter to me— Post Office and Custom house commotions— Reported call of Congress 1st. Monday in September.
19. V. Friday.

list.item: Showery night and day— Invincible indolence

div.p: Bass— Son of Samuel Bass from Braintree Vermont with Cheese at 12 1/2 cents a pound— Visits from Mr Lunt, Captain Whitney and Mr Brigham— Walk to Mrs Ann Adams’s—unwell—confined to her chamber. Garden—Nursery—Seminary— Evening at Mr Beale’s— E. Price Greenleaf there
20. V:30. Saturday.

John Q. Adams 2d. with his cousin Foster here this morning— My Son. Charles F. [symbols] came out from Boston with his family; and Catherineand Mary AnnMr Appleton of Cambridge was here this afternoon—and Alexander H. Everett Mr Appleton brought me several of my Letters to the late J. Bailey—now belonging to J. Appleton Bailey a boy 9 years of age. Received and answered a Letter, from L. C. A. also the Proclamation of President Van Buren calling Congress to meet 4 September next.— Garden Nursery— Seminary— Discouragements multitudes of Trees killed— Black Jack Oaks dead to the ground All last years seedling peach-trees killed—and many others— First appearance of 2 seedling peach trees—4 Seedling Pear-trees discovered close to the old Althaea
21. V:15 Sunday

Heard Mr Lamson from James 5.11. and 1. Corinthians 4.5— Read Saurin’s Sermon 9 of Volume 9. and Dr Frothinghams Sermon, upon hard times— Mr Lamson dined with us. Evening at Mrs Thomas Greenleaf’s. Met there Mr Beale— His daughter Ann and Dr Woodward—
22. V: Monday— Sun rose hazy— Soon clouded— Rain the whole day and Evening— Confined to the house— Chilly— Draft of an Oration for 4. July—
23. V:30. Tuesday

Fair day. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— Alpheus Spear came and settled his rent for the Mount Wollaston farm— Call twice at the Quincy Stone bank— Deposit and Check— Garden, Nursery and Seminary— John Quincy told me of Dr Woodwards Engagement to Miss Mary-Ann Greenleaf— Pear and Cherry trees in full bloom— Met Mr Minot of Rainsford’s Island, and Harvey Field— Charles sprained his ancle—
24. V. Wednesday.

Morning fair— M’Carthy an Irish workman seeking employment— Planted Apples and seeds winter rotted— At the Bank— Minott Thayer— Will come Thursday 1. June at 1/2 past 11. with the Committee of Members of the Legislature from the 12th. Congressional District— After dinner— Ebenezer Adams 75—9th. of May. came and took me in his chaise to the Stone quarries where Willard with 90 men is at work— They want a road thence to the Captain’s Bridge, and want me to contribute to make it— Rain began as we were returning— Found Persico here with Mr Alessandro, Neapolitan vice-Consul at Boston— Persico is wanting to sell his Pictures to the Boston Athenaeum— Day wasted.

25. VI. Thursday— All Night, all this day and Evening, steady gentle rain, with chilly east wind— Confined to the House. Answered duplicate from Newbury-Port— Tocqueville. Oration for the 4th. of July— Letters every day from my wife

Wavering policy of Mr Van Buren’s administration— Analysis of the Declaration of Independence— Of the Articles of Confederation. Of the Constitution of the United States— Letter from Benjamin Lundy, about a Petition to Congress against the annexation of Texas to this Union—
26. IV:30. Friday.

Mr William Spear was here this morning. Mr Faxon proposes to purchase the pew N 75 in the Stone Meeting house, for 225. dollars to be paid next February to which I agreed— Harvey Field not likely to pay his note— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— Cold—cheerless day, with wind at North-east— Visited Garden—Nursery and Seminary—discouraged— Almost all my trees fail. Peaches nearly destroyed— White Oaks and Shagbarks blighted.— Nothing new but precarious apple-seedlings— Letter to the Newbury-Port Committee— Letter from C. W. Upham Salem— Tocqueville— Oration
27. V. Saturday.

Fair day, but cold. I visited my garden, nursery and seminary, and mourned over the multitudes of my lost trees, no small number of which had been nine or ten years growing—the honey-locust, the willow-oak, the Nettle trees, the sweet gum or liquid amber, almost all my last year’s seedlings of every description, winter-killed— I planted sundry withered Apples and pears—remarked that my wild strawberries are covered with blossoms, and observed the remarkable difference between the opening vegetation of the Shagbark and Pignut hickories.— Midshipman John Quincy was here this morning, and Mr Beale and his daughter Ann in the Evening— My draught for an Oration steadily proceeds in melancholy dulness.
28. IV:30. Sunday

Heard Mr Farley of Providence, in the morning from Psalm 55.19. and in the afternoon from John 19.25. Jesus and his mother. Mr Farley dined with us— Conversation with him upon his morning text. Mr Whitney gave notice that the communion would be administered next Sunday. After the second service Mr Price Greenleaf walked with me in my garden and Nursery—found a worm in the stem-bud of my most promising Nursery seedling shagbark walnut tree— Also in the stem-leaf of the most prosperous Apple-seedling— I read the tenth Sermon of the 9th. volume of Saurin—on tribute, and a very curious discourse at the present day— Cold, but fair.
29. IV. Monday

My draught of an Oration for the 4th. of July absorbs my time and much disheartens me— Midshipman John Quincy was here this morning; and dined with us— Widow of Samuel Spear once Baxter came with her Niece to enquire about a pension. Her husband served in the revolutionary War, but she was not married till after the Peace. I advised her to authenticate Evidence, both of the Service and the marriage— Charles and his wife went to Dorchester to see Mr and Mrs James Seaver— Mrs Miller and her daughter came to take Mrs Charles to ride with them. I visited Charles house— Beautiful prospect from the front eastern chamber— Cold evening.
30. IV. Tuesday— Sun rose hazy.

Charles went in to Boston, and returned to dine— Mr Beale came while I was visiting my garden, with a subscription paper for the organ erecting in the Stone meeting house; but I decline. Kirk came from William Hobart, with an old bill for Oats, and recalled me from the garden for the day— After dinner Mr Lunt, and Mr E. Price Greenleaf came to inspect the town Library, and my own Transient call from President Quincy, and his son— Mrs. Frothingham with her son Thomas and Mrs Edward Everett with her daughters Ann and Charlotte came out from Boston and took tea with us— My task on the draught of the Oration, fell short in this days performance
31. IV. Wednesday.

The draught of my Oration absorbs the whole of my time, except that which I waste upon my seedling plants— The midshipman John Q Adams dined here with Mrs. Phineas Foster’s daughter Fanny— After dinner I walked up to the House, which my Son Charles is building, and went up to the second floor; the prospect from which North-East and South is magnificent— My visitations to the Garden, Nursery and Seminary are very unsatisfactory— Louisa C. Smith came out from Boston to spend some time with us. Charles and his wife visited Mr. and Mrs Seaver at Dorchester—
